trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting degraded status on Azure Traffic Manager
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting degraded status on Azure Traffic Manager

trans-unit.source: How to troubleshoot Traffic Manager profiles when it shows as degraded status.
trans-unit.target: How to troubleshoot Traffic Manager profiles when it shows as degraded status.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting degraded status on Azure Traffic Manager
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting degraded status on Azure Traffic Manager

trans-unit.source: This page will describe how to troubleshoot Azure Traffic Manager profile which is showing a degraded status, and provide some key points to understand about traffic manager probes.
trans-unit.target: This page will describe how to troubleshoot Azure Traffic Manager profile which is showing a degraded status, and provide some key points to understand about traffic manager probes.

trans-unit.source: You have configured a Traffic Manager profile pointing to some of your .cloudapp.net hosted services and after a few seconds you see the Status as Degraded.
trans-unit.target: You have configured a Traffic Manager profile pointing to some of your .cloudapp.net hosted services and after a few seconds you see the Status as Degraded.

trans-unit.source: degradedstate
trans-unit.target: degradedstate

trans-unit.source: If you go into the Endpoints tab of that profile you will see one or more of the endpoints in an Offline status:
trans-unit.target: If you go into the Endpoints tab of that profile you will see one or more of the endpoints in an Offline status:

trans-unit.source: offline
trans-unit.target: offline

trans-unit.source: Important notes about Traffic Manager probing
trans-unit.target: Important notes about Traffic Manager probing

trans-unit.source: Traffic Manager only considers an endpoint as ONLINE if the probe gets a 200 back from the probe path.
trans-unit.target: Traffic Manager only considers an endpoint as ONLINE if the probe gets a 200 back from the probe path.

trans-unit.source: A 30x redirect (or any other non-200 response) will fail, even if the redirected URL returns a 200.
trans-unit.target: A 30x redirect (or any other non-200 response) will fail, even if the redirected URL returns a 200.

trans-unit.source: For HTTPs probes, certificate errors are ignored.
trans-unit.target: For HTTPs probes, certificate errors are ignored.

trans-unit.source: The actual content of the probe path doesn’t matter, as long as a 200 is returned.
trans-unit.target: The actual content of the probe path doesn’t matter, as long as a 200 is returned.

trans-unit.source: A common technique if the actual website content doesn’t return a 200 (ie. if the ASP pages redirect to an ACS login page or some other CNAME URL) is to set the path to something like “/favicon.ico”.
trans-unit.target: A common technique if the actual website content doesn’t return a 200 (ie. if the ASP pages redirect to an ACS login page or some other CNAME URL) is to set the path to something like “/favicon.ico”.

trans-unit.source: Best practice is to set the Probe path to something which has enough logic to determine if the site is up or down.
trans-unit.target: Best practice is to set the Probe path to something which has enough logic to determine if the site is up or down.

trans-unit.source: In the above example setting the path to “/favicon.ico” you are only testing if w3wp.exe is responding, but not if your website is healthy.
trans-unit.target: In the above example setting the path to “/favicon.ico” you are only testing if w3wp.exe is responding, but not if your website is healthy.

trans-unit.source: A better option would be to set a path to something such as “/Probe.aspx”, and within Probe.aspx include enough logic to determine if your site is healthy (ie. check perf counters to make sure you aren’t at 100% CPU or receiving a large number of failed requests, attempt to access resources such as the database or session state to make sure the application’s logic is working, etc).
trans-unit.target: A better option would be to set a path to something such as “/Probe.aspx”, and within Probe.aspx include enough logic to determine if your site is healthy (ie. check perf counters to make sure you aren’t at 100% CPU or receiving a large number of failed requests, attempt to access resources such as the database or session state to make sure the application’s logic is working, etc).

trans-unit.source: If all endpoints in a profile are degraded then Traffic Manager will treat all endpoints as healthy and route traffic to all endpoints.
trans-unit.target: If all endpoints in a profile are degraded then Traffic Manager will treat all endpoints as healthy and route traffic to all endpoints.

trans-unit.source: This is to ensure that any potential problem with the probing mechanism which results in incorrectly failed probes will not result in a complete outage of your service.
trans-unit.target: This is to ensure that any potential problem with the probing mechanism which results in incorrectly failed probes will not result in a complete outage of your service.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: One tool for troubleshooting Traffic Manager probe failures is wget.
trans-unit.target: One tool for troubleshooting Traffic Manager probe failures is wget.

trans-unit.source: You can get the binaries and dependencies package from [wget](http://gnuwin32.sourceforge.net/packages/wget.htm).
trans-unit.target: You can get the binaries and dependencies package from [wget](http://gnuwin32.sourceforge.net/packages/wget.htm).

trans-unit.source: Note that you can use other programs such as Fiddler or curl instead of wget – basically you just need something that will show you the raw HTTP response.
trans-unit.target: Note that you can use other programs such as Fiddler or curl instead of wget – basically you just need something that will show you the raw HTTP response.

trans-unit.source: Once you have wget installed, go to a command prompt and run wget against the URL + Probe port & path that is configured in Traffic Manager.
trans-unit.target: Once you have wget installed, go to a command prompt and run wget against the URL + Probe port & path that is configured in Traffic Manager.

trans-unit.source: For this example it would be http://watestsdp2008r2.cloudapp.net:80/Probe.
trans-unit.target: For this example it would be http://watestsdp2008r2.cloudapp.net:80/Probe.

trans-unit.source: troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: Using Wget:
trans-unit.target: Using Wget:

trans-unit.source: wget
trans-unit.target: wget

trans-unit.source: Notice that wget indicates that the URL returned a 301 redirect to http://watestsdp2008r2.cloudapp.net/Default.aspx.
trans-unit.target: Notice that wget indicates that the URL returned a 301 redirect to http://watestsdp2008r2.cloudapp.net/Default.aspx.

trans-unit.source: As we know from the “Important notes about Traffic Manager probing” section above, a 30x redirect is considered a failure by Traffic Manager probing and this will cause the probe to report Offline.
trans-unit.target: As we know from the “Important notes about Traffic Manager probing” section above, a 30x redirect is considered a failure by Traffic Manager probing and this will cause the probe to report Offline.

trans-unit.source: At this point it is a simple matter to check the website configuration and make sure that a 200 is returned from the /Probe path (or reconfigure the Traffic Manager probe to point to a path which will return a 200).
trans-unit.target: At this point it is a simple matter to check the website configuration and make sure that a 200 is returned from the /Probe path (or reconfigure the Traffic Manager probe to point to a path which will return a 200).

trans-unit.source: If your probe is using HTTPs protocol you will want to add the “--no-check-certificate” parameter to wget so that it will ignore the certificate mismatch on the cloudapp.net URL.
trans-unit.target: If your probe is using HTTPs protocol you will want to add the “--no-check-certificate” parameter to wget so that it will ignore the certificate mismatch on the cloudapp.net URL.
